contextId.information: "They" refers to discretion and understanding, which are spoken of as if they were persons who could rescue someone else. AT: "You will know to stay away from what is evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: They will rescue you from the way of evil

contextId.information: The writer speaks of wisdom and discretion as if they were people who save the one who possesses them. AT: "If you have wisdom and discretion, you will save yourself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Wisdom and discretion will save you

contextId.information: The writer speaks of "covenant faithfulness" and "trustworthiness" as if they were people who could leave someone. The negative command can be stated positively. AT: "Make sure always to practice covenant faithfulness and to be trustworthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Do not let covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness ever leave you

contextId.information: The writer speaks of wisdom as if it were a woman and of wisdom giving great honor to a person as if wisdom lifted that person to a high position. AT: "If you cherish wisdom, she will give you great honor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Cherish wisdom and she will exalt you

contextId.information: The writer speaks of a wicked person being unable to avoid the consequences of his iniquities as if those iniquities were people who capture the wicked person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "A wicked person's own iniquities will seize him" or "A wicked person will be unable to avoid the consequences of his iniquities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: A wicked person will be seized by his own iniquities

contextId.information: This implies that the disaster is chasing him like a person or an animal, and that it will catch him soon. AT: "his disaster will catch him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: his disaster will overtake him

contextId.information: Here wisdom is spoken of as if it were a person. AT: "Value wisdom as you would love your sister" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Say to wisdom, "You are my sister

contextId.information: Here wisdom is imagined as a woman. If a language does not allow this kind of metaphor, other possible translations are: 1) "Is not wisdom like a woman who calls out?" 2) "Does not a woman named Wisdom call out?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Does not Wisdom call out?

contextId.information: Prudence is also represented here as a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: I, Wisdom, live with Prudence

contextId.information: This is wisdom speaking about herself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: I was born ... I was there

contextId.information: This is still wisdom talking about herself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: listen to me

contextId.information: This is still wisdom talking about herself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: finds me ... find me ... hate me

contextId.information: It is possible to translate "foolishness" as a description. AT: "A foolish woman." However, if a language allows wisdom to be personified, as in the previous part of this chapter, it may also allow foolishness to be personified. AT: "The woman Foolishness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The woman of foolishness

contextId.information: "Righteousness" represents a way of life approved by Yahweh. This quality acts like a person who protects. AT: "A way of life approved by Yahweh protects" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Righteousness protects those

contextId.information: "Disaster" is given human characteristics like the ability to run. AT: "Sinners have trouble wherever they go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Disaster runs after sinners

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the appetite as if it were a person who works on behalf of the laborer. This means that the person who labors is motivated by his desire to eat. AT: "The laborer works to satisfy his appetite" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The laborer's appetite works for him

contextId.information: This speaks of how laziness causes a person to sleep a lot as if laziness forcefully throws the person into sleep. AT: "Laziness makes a person sleep a lot" or "A lazy person sleeps a lot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Laziness throws a person into a deep sleep

contextId.information: The writer speaks as though violence were a person who could drag other people away. God will punish wicked people who harm their innocent neighbors because of the violent deeds they have done. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The violence of the wicked will drag them away

contextId.information: The writer speaks of a person's appetite, the physical desire for food and drink, as if it were a person who could desire something. The word "wicked" is a nominal adjective that refers to evil people; the word "evil" is a metonym for evil deeds. AT: "Evil people desire to do evil deeds just as they desire to eat and drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The appetite of the wicked craves evil

contextId.information: The writer speaks of what a person wants as if it were a person who could kill a lazy person. Here the lazy person wants to be idle and not work. AT: "A lazy person only wants to be idle, and because of that he will die" or "A lazy person will die because he does not want to work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
contextId.quote: The desire of the lazy kills him

contextId.information: The writer speaks as if a rod and reproof were people who could give wisdom as a physical gift. AT: "If a parent uses the rod on his child and reproves him, the child will become wise" or "If parents discipline their child and tell him when he has done wrong, the child will learn to live wisely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The rod and reproof give wisdom
